a broadcast receiver and content providers but um there the main two ones are really the activity in the service
and just think of it as the visual in the background uh the intent is the thing that you say I want to do
something and it's a little bit of an abstraction layer to say um instead of
you can say I want to launch this activity but then the system is responsible for coming back with that
activity for you you don't just say new for example uh the other thing is you can say I want to do something I want to

whatever okay and then the last thing is the Manifest the Android manifest is the
application uh sort of specification that tells the operating system here's
what I can do the activities that I respond to the services the permissions that I need so that's a static piece of
information that goes with the application and allows the the launcher
and other act app um applications to know what what it can
do the challenges when it comes to uh bringing J Ruby over into Android is
there are limitations on mobile Hardware J Ruby wasn't specifically designed to to operate in a low memory environment a
slow processor environment um clearly the mobile Hardware is getting better but people are trying to push the uh the
Android operating system into many different devices there's watches coming out with it running in it so clearly

embedding blocks there you could lose 20 frames in your stack um and so sooner or
later you run out of Stack space the main place that you're going to hit this is either in parsing um your um uh your
R your Ruby code or in embedding um widgets if you're building a a
UI the the one to when you're loading code is really easy to solve because you
can wrap it in a thread and and just load it in the background and you can specify how much stack space you want
